1 \defgroup pluggable-session-storage Pluggable Session Storage
2 \ingroup session-storage
3 
4 \details
5 
6 Pluggable session storage is the storage implemented by the user.
7 
8 For example, it could be used to implement High-Availability (HA) Solutions:
9 
10 One can implement a Pluggable Session Storage that stores data to shared storage.
11 If one server fails and another reserve server activates, the Handler can restore session states from the shared storage.
12 
13 Such storage should implement the OnixS::B3::BOE::SessionStorage interface.
14 
15 \section pluggable-storage-implementing Implementing Pluggable Storage
16 
17 There are a few basic rules that should be applied to the implementation of Pluggable Storage.
18 
19 * **The user should manage the life-cycle of the storage**. The Handler treats the instance of a Pluggable Storage as a
20 "foreign" object and never attempts to delete it.
21 On the other hand, there is a strong requirement to keep storage instance valid until the OnixS::B3::BOE::Session
22 instance is destroyed.
23 
24 * **Be as fast as possible**. The Pluggable Storage is a part of the message send/receive path, so it has a direct
25 effect on the sending/receiving latency and overall throughput of the system.
26 
27 * **Avoid throwing exceptions**. Exceptions thrown from Pluggable Storage callbacks immediately break a session.
28 
29 * **Don't make assumptions about the parameters' life-cycle**. Whenever you need to keep such data for separate usage,
30 you should make copies of messages or memory blocks
31  and store them in an appropriate place, but don't keep raw pointers, passed to callbacks.
32 
33 * **No synchronization is required**. The Handler manages all synchronization issues, so all methods of Pluggable
34 Storage are called sequentially.
35 
36 * **Track message numbers when the message is logged**. Message sequence numbers should be tracked while messages are
37 logged,
38 i.e. during OnixS::B3::BOE::SessionStorage::storeInboundMessage or OnixS::B3::BOE::SessionStorage::storeOutboundMessage
39 methods.
40 These numbers should be kept and returned to the Handler through OnixS::B3::BOE::SessionStorage::inSeqNum() and
41 OnixS::B3::BOE::SessionStorage::outSeqNum() calls.
42 
43 \section pluggable-storage-call-order Call Order of Pluggable Storage Methods
44 
45 This section explains how different methods of Pluggable Storage are called in different situations.
46 
47 \subsection incoming-message-handling Incoming message handling
48 
49 * When there is a session-level message, the following methods are called:
50  * OnixS::B3::BOE::SessionStorage::storeInboundMessage
51  * OnixS::B3::BOE::SessionListener methods, if the listener is present
52 * When there is an application-level message, the call order is reversed:
53  * OnixS::B3::BOE::SessionListener methods, if the listener is present
54  * OnixS::B3::BOE::SessionStorage::storeInboundMessage.
55 
56 If the user's code throws an exception on any stage, the session becomes disconnected, and subsequent steps are omitted.
57 
58 \subsection outgoing-message-handling Outgoing message handling
59 
60 * OnixS::B3::BOE::SessionListener methods.
61 * OnixS::B3::BOE::SessionStorage::storeOutboundMessage.
62
